text:
library(readxl)

Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

library(readr)
crumbs: Task 3: Combining Excel and Delimited Data

title: Task 1: Conceptual Questions
text:
If your working directory is myfolder/homework/, what relative path would you specify to get the file located at myfolder/MyData.csv?

../MyData.csv

What are the major benefits of using R projects?

The major benefits of using R projects are to keep an analysis together. Through the R project there is a shared working directory, workspace, history, and folder structure and source documents. This keeps everything necessary for the project together and easily shareable for collaboration, as long as file paths are relative.

What is git and what is github?

Git is version control software that tracks changes committed to the files and allows multiple users to work on the same project. Github is a hosting service on the internet that allows us to do Git-based projects and share them widely.

What are the two main differences between a tibble and a data.frame?

The two main differences between a tibble and a data frame are the specialized format in which tibbles are printed and that tibbles are not coerced to vectors when subsetting a single column using [ ]. Tibbles are a specialized form of a dataset.

Rewrite the following nested function call using BaseR’s chaining operator:
arrange(filter(select(as_tibble(iris), starts_with(“Petal”), Species), Petal.Length < 1.55), Species)


iris |> as.data.frame() |> select(starts_with(“Petal”), Species) |> filter(Petal.Length < 1.55) |> arrange(Species)

text:

title: Task 2: Reading Delimited Data
text:
Glass Data

Read in data:


glass_data <- read_csv("https://www4.stat.ncsu.edu/online/datasets/glass.data", 
         col_names = c("Id", "RI", "Na", "Mg", "Al", "Si", "K", "Ca", "Ba", "Fe", "Type_of_Glass"))

Rows: 214 Columns: 11
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
dbl (11): Id, RI, Na, Mg, Al, Si, K, Ca, Ba, Fe, Type_of_Glass

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

glass_data

# A tibble: 214 × 11
      Id    RI    Na    Mg    Al    Si     K    Ca    Ba    Fe Type_of_Glass
   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>         <dbl>
 1     1  1.52  13.6  4.49  1.1   71.8  0.06  8.75     0  0                1
 2     2  1.52  13.9  3.6   1.36  72.7  0.48  7.83     0  0                1
 3     3  1.52  13.5  3.55  1.54  73.0  0.39  7.78     0  0                1
 4     4  1.52  13.2  3.69  1.29  72.6  0.57  8.22     0  0                1
 5     5  1.52  13.3  3.62  1.24  73.1  0.55  8.07     0  0                1
 6     6  1.52  12.8  3.61  1.62  73.0  0.64  8.07     0  0.26             1
 7     7  1.52  13.3  3.6   1.14  73.1  0.58  8.17     0  0                1
 8     8  1.52  13.2  3.61  1.05  73.2  0.57  8.24     0  0                1
 9     9  1.52  14.0  3.58  1.37  72.1  0.56  8.3      0  0                1
10    10  1.52  13    3.6   1.36  73.0  0.57  8.4      0  0.11             1
# ℹ 204 more rows



Start a Chain to Mutate Type_of_Glass column:
Continue Chain to Filter Data:


glass_data <- glass_data |>
  mutate(Type_of_Glass = ifelse(Type_of_Glass == 1, 
                                "building_windows_float_processed",
                                ifelse(Type_of_Glass == 2, 
                                       "building_windows_non_float_processed", 
                                       ifelse(Type_of_Glass == 3, 
                                              "vehicle_windows_float_processed",
                                              ifelse(Type_of_Glass == 4, 
                                                     "vehicle_windows_non_float_processed",
                                                     ifelse(Type_of_Glass == 5,
                                                            "containers",
                                                            ifelse(Type_of_Glass == 6,
                                                                   "tableware",
                                                                   ifelse(Type_of_Glass == 7, 
                                                                          "headlamps", 
                                                                          "error")))))))) |>
  filter(Fe < 0.2, Type_of_Glass %in% c("tableware", "headlamps"))
glass_data

# A tibble: 38 × 11

   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>

 9   185  1.51  17.4  0     0.34  75.4  0     6.65  0        0 tableware    
10   186  1.51  13.7  3.2   1.81  72.8  1.76  5.43  1.19     0 headlamps

title: Task 2: Reading Delimited Data
text:
Yeast Data

Read in Data:


yeast_data <- read_fwf("https://www4.stat.ncsu.edu/online/datasets/yeast.data",
                       fwf_widths(c(12, 6, 6, 6, 6, 6, 6, 6, 6, 3),
                                  col_names = c("seq_name", "mcg", "gvh", "alm", "mit", "erl", "pox", "vac", "nuc", "class")))

Rows: 1484 Columns: 10
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

chr (2): seq_name, class
dbl (8): mcg, gvh, alm, mit, erl, pox, vac, nuc

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

yeast_data

# A tibble: 1,484 × 10
   seq_name     mcg   gvh   alm   mit   erl   pox   vac   nuc class
   <chr>      <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>
 1 ADT1_YEAST  0.58  0.61  0.47  0.13   0.5   0    0.48  0.22 MIT  
 2 ADT2_YEAST  0.43  0.67  0.48  0.27   0.5   0    0.53  0.22 MIT  
 3 ADT3_YEAST  0.64  0.62  0.49  0.15   0.5   0    0.53  0.22 MIT  
 4 AAR2_YEAST  0.58  0.44  0.57  0.13   0.5   0    0.54  0.22 NUC  
 5 AATM_YEAST  0.42  0.44  0.48  0.54   0.5   0    0.48  0.22 MIT  
 6 AATC_YEAST  0.51  0.4   0.56  0.17   0.5   0.5  0.49  0.22 CYT  
 7 ABC1_YEAST  0.5   0.54  0.48  0.65   0.5   0    0.53  0.22 MIT  
 8 BAF1_YEAST  0.48  0.45  0.59  0.2    0.5   0    0.58  0.34 NUC  
 9 ABF2_YEAST  0.55  0.5   0.66  0.36   0.5   0    0.49  0.22 MIT  
10 ABP1_YEAST  0.4   0.39  0.6   0.15   0.5   0    0.58  0.3  CYT  
# ℹ 1,474 more rows



Start a Chain to Remove Specified Columns:
Continue Chain to Add Specified Columns:


yeast_data <- yeast_data |>
  select(!c(seq_name, nuc)) |>
  group_by(class) |>
  mutate(across((mcg:vac), list(mean = mean, median = median), .names = "{.col}_{.fn}"))
yeast_data

title: Task 3: Combining Excel and Delimited Data
text:
Read in and manipulate data

Import White Wine Data:


white_wine_data <- read_excel("../white-wine.xlsx")
white_wine_data

# A tibble: 4,898 × 12
   `fixed acidity` `volatile acidity` `citric acid` `residual sugar` chlorides
             <dbl>              <dbl>         <dbl>            <dbl>     <dbl>
 1               7               0.27          0.36             20.7     0.045
 2              63               0.3           0.34              1.6     0.049
 3              81               0.28          0.4               6.9     0.05 
 4              72               0.23          0.32              8.5     0.058
 5              72               0.23          0.32              8.5     0.058
 6              81               0.28          0.4               6.9     0.05

10              81               0.22          0.43              1.5     0.044
# ℹ 4,888 more rows
# ℹ 7 more variables: `free sulfur dioxide` <dbl>,
#   `total sulfur dioxide` <dbl>, density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>,
#   alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>



Standardize Column Names for White Wine Data:


Read in data from second excel sheet of white wine data (variable names)
Overwrite column names


excel_sheets("../white-wine.xlsx") #find name of second sheet

[1] "white-wine" "variables" 

var_names <- read_excel("../white-wine.xlsx", sheet = "variables") #read in second sheet
var_names #view variable names

# A tibble: 12 × 1
   Variables           
   <chr>               
 1 fixed_acidity       
 2 volatile_acidity    
 3 citric_acid         
 4 residual_sugar      
 5 chlorides           
 6 free_sulfur_dioxide 
 7 total_sulfur_dioxide
 8 density             
 9 pH                  
10 sulphates           
11 alcohol             
12 quality             

for (i in 1:dim(white_wine_data)[2]) {
  colnames(white_wine_data)[i] <- var_names[i,]
} #overwrite column names with those from the second excel sheet
white_wine_data #view data with overwritten column names

# A tibble: 4,898 × 12
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>

 7            62             0.32        0.16            7       0.045
 8             7             0.27        0.36           20.7     0.045
 9            63             0.3         0.34            1.6     0.049
10            81             0.22        0.43            1.5     0.044
# ℹ 4,888 more rows
# ℹ 7 more variables: free_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>, total_sulfur_dioxide <dbl>,
#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>



Add a column to indicate that these wines are white:


white_wine_data <- white_wine_data |>
  mutate(wine_type = "white")
white_wine_data #view data with wine_type variable added

# A tibble: 4,898 × 13
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid residual_sugar chlorides
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>     <dbl>

10            81             0.22        0.43            1.5     0.044

#   density <dbl>, pH <dbl>, sulphates <dbl>, alcohol <dbl>, quality <dbl>,
#   wine_type <chr>



Read in and manipulate red wine data:


Read in red wine data
Check column types
Overwrite column names
Add wine_type variable


red_wine_data <- read_delim("https://www4.stat.ncsu.edu/online/datasets/red-wine.csv", 
                            delim = ";") #read in data

Rows: 1599 Columns: 12
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ";"
dbl (12): fixed acidity, volatile acidity, citric acid, residual sugar, chlo...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

for (i in 1:dim(red_wine_data)[2]) {
  colnames(red_wine_data)[i] <- var_names[i,]
} #overwrite column names to standardize
red_wine_data <- red_wine_data |> 
  mutate(wine_type = "red")
red_wine_data

crumbs: Task 3: Combining Excel and Delimited Data

title: Task 3: Combining Excel and Delimited Data
text:
Combine data and manipulate further

Combine the datasets:


wine_data <- bind_rows(white_wine_data, red_wine_data)


Filter
Sort
Select columns
Add mean and standard deviation of alcohol variable grouped by quality:


wine_data <- wine_data |>
  filter(quality > 6.5, alcohol < 132) |>
  arrange(desc(quality)) |>
  select(contains("acid"), alcohol, wine_type, quality) |> 
  group_by(quality) |>
  mutate(mean_alcohol = mean(alcohol), sd_alcohol = sd(alcohol))
wine_data

# A tibble: 1,206 × 8
# Groups:   quality [3]
   fixed_acidity volatile_acidity citric_acid alcohol wine_type quality
           <dbl>            <dbl>       <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>       <dbl>
